description:
Vanessa cardui, commonly known as the painted lady or cosmopolitan, is a butterfly species that belongs to the family Nymphalidae. It is one of the most widely distributed butterfly species in the world, found on every continent except Antarctica.

The painted lady has a wingspan of approximately 5-6 inches (12-15 cm). The upper side of the wings is orange-brown with black and white markings, while the underside is patterned in shades of brown and gray. The species exhibits sexual dimorphism, with females generally having more pronounced markings and a more muted coloration compared to the males.

Vanessa cardui is known for its remarkable migratory behavior, with some populations undertaking long-distance migrations spanning thousands of miles. The species' larvae, or caterpillars, feed on a variety of host plants, primarily from the Asteraceae family, such as thistles and burdocks.

The painted lady is considered a generalist species, able to adapt to a wide range of habitats, from deserts and grasslands to urban areas. Its resilience and adaptability contribute to its global distribution and success as a species.
